Chapter 3, Section 2: Distinguishing the Differences. Thus far, the dharmas of the great wholesome ground have been explained.

The name great afflictive ground refers to the great afflictive ground. The dharmas that exist in the great afflictive ground are called the dharmas of the great afflictive ground, meaning the dharmas that always exist in defiled minds.
What are those dharmas?
Verse:ğŸ”½Delusion, negligence, laziness, lack of faith,
stupefaction, and agitation are always only defiled.
Treatise:
Why are these six called the dharmas of the great afflictive ground?
Because they always accompany defiled minds.
The term defiled in the verse means the meaning of defiled mind.
Moreover, negligence, etc., and ignorance should be known as the objects of abandonment by the aforementioned non-negligence, vigor, faith, tranquility, and equanimity, respectively.

Delusion is stupidity. It is the obstruction to understanding the true nature of knowable objects. Its characteristic is a lack of discernment. It is called stupidity, which is the same as ignorance, lack of knowledge, and lack of manifestation.
Carelessness is negligence. It is called carelessness because one abandons one's own interests and indulges in one's emotions.

Laziness is sloth. It is called laziness because it is the outflow of ignorance, etc., which reduces one's ability to engage in wholesome activities and makes one brave and bold in engaging in unwholesome activities.
For this reason, it is said to be the nature of contemptible effort. Because one diligently engages in contemptible and defiled [activities], it is called laziness.

Lack of faith is the lack of clarity in the mind. It is the outflow of wrong views, etc. It is called lack of faith because one openly denigrates the truths, realities, meditative absorptions, and attainments, and because one does not openly acknowledge the causes such as generosity and their effects.

Dullness is the heaviness of the mind produced by drowsiness, sluggishness, and lack of joy. It is called sluggishness because it covers over the mind, making it dull and incapable, due to its nature of being dazed and confused.
Therefore it is said to be what is eliminated by serenity.

The mind is the cause that produces the great elements, and on the basis of this, the quality of heaviness of the body arises. It is metaphorically said to be torpor, but in reality it is not torpor, because it is the object of the body consciousness.
However, because this torpor is covered by ignorance, the treatise does not say that it is a great ground of defilement.
Some say:
The treatise speaks of the name of ignorance, only because it resembles torpor.
Because the nature of ignorance is a universal, it is a ground of defilement, and it is not said to be so.
Some say: This name generally refers to two meanings.
Agitation refers to agitation born from relatives, discursive thought, etc., which is the quality of not causing the mind to be tranquil, and is called agitation.

When the mind combines with these, it goes beyond the path, and improper attention, loss of mindfulness, distraction, incorrect knowledge, and wrong resolve, which have already been explained as mental factors common to all unwholesome minds, although present here, are not mentioned, just as the wholesome roots of non-delusion are not mentioned among the mental factors common to all wholesome minds.
Only all defiled minds always have these six.
Thus the mental factors common to all defiled minds have been explained.ğŸ”½The name of the mental factors common to all unwholesome minds is the mental factors common to all unwholesome minds.
What are the mental factors that are always present in unwholesome minds?
Verse:
Only shamelessness and lack of conscience are universal in unwholesome minds.
Treatise:
Only two mental factors are always present in all unwholesome minds, namely shamelessness and lack of conscience. Therefore only these two are called mental factors common to this class.
The characteristics of these two mental factors will be revealed later.
Thus the great unwholesome factors have been explained.

The name of the stage of minor afflictions is the stage of minor afflictions. The factors that are present in this stage are called the factors of the stage of minor afflictions, meaning the factors that are slightly defiled and occur together with the mind.
What are those factors?
The verse says:
Anger, concealment, stinginess, jealousy, malice, resentment, deceit, flattery, and arrogance,
These kinds of factors are called the factors of the stage of minor afflictions.
The commentary says:
The word kind is used to include the meanings of intolerance, displeasure, and resentment.
Minor means small, indicating that they do not occur together with all defiled minds, and also that they are not associated [with the mind].

They are only eliminated by cultivation, arise together with the mental consciousness, are associated with ignorance, and their characteristics will be explained in the section on secondary afflictions.ğŸ”½These mental factors all have real natures, because in the various objects of the single category, the various aspects arise simultaneously.
Because it is not possible for a single substance to have different aspects simultaneously, like the object.
However, because they are controlled by other dharmas, we see that their continuity changes and arises differently.
We directly perceive that the power of such things as oil, dirt, water, and wind controls the continuity of a lamp, causing it to have brightness, darkness, sound, movement, etc.
Thus we have explained the categories and distinctions of the dharmas common to all minds, etc.
There are also these other indeterminate mental activities, such as remorse, sloth, applied thought, sustained thought, etc., which are generally called indeterminate dharmas.
Now we must determine the number of mental activities that are necessarily generated together with all minds.
How many mental activities are there in a single mind?
A verse says:
Because desire has applied and sustained thought,
in a good mind there are twenty-two mental activities. Sometimes remorse is added to this.
In a bad mind that is not common to all, and in a mind associated with views, there are only twenty.
Four passions, anger, etc., and remorse make twenty-one.
There are eighteen with hindrances, and twelve without hindrances are allowed.
Sleep is universal and does not contradict, and if present, all increase by one.
The treatise says:
In the desire realm, the category of mind is fivefold. The wholesome is only one.
The unwholesome has two: that which arises together with non-shared ignorance, and that which arises together with other afflictions, etc.
The indeterminate has two: that which is indeterminate with hindrances, and that which is indeterminate without hindrances.

Thus, in all the mind categories of the desire realm, they are definitely always associated with initial and sustained thought. Therefore, the wholesome mind category has twenty-two mental factors arising together, namely the ten universal mental factors, the ten wholesome factors, and the two inconstant ones, namely initial and sustained thought.
Among them, effort and equanimity should not arise together, because their modes of activity contradict each other.
Like advancing and stopping, creating and abandoning, the principles do not occur simultaneously.
The scriptures also prohibit the arising of these two together, because they speak of the time and non-time for cultivating the two dharmas.
As a scripture says:
If the mind is dull, then one should cultivate investigation of the Dharma, vigor, and joy, but to cultivate tranquility, concentration, and equanimity is untimely.
If the mind is agitated, then one should cultivate tranquility, concentration, and equanimity, but to cultivate investigation of the Dharma, vigor, and joy is untimely.
There is no error in their simultaneous occurrence, because they are not in opposition.

One who abides in correct principles generates correct practices and does not cease, which is called vigor. At that time, one abandons incorrect practices and is impartial, which is called equanimity.

Moreover, in regard to correct and incorrect practices, equanimity is like holding a scale, advancing and stopping equally. Therefore, equanimity and vigor mutually accord with each other, and the generation of good and the cessation of evil are not in opposition.
If one grasps one and abandons one in regard to the object, then there is this error of opposition.
The indeterminate dharmas are of two kinds: remorse and sleep.

Neither of these two dharmas penetrates the three realms and the six consciousnesses, nor is it only impure or only defiled, therefore the class of good mind is not always accompanied by remorse, but it may be present, sometimes increasing to twenty-three.
As for remorse, it is called remorse because it takes remorse as its object, like the concentration of signlessness.
Some say that signlessness and the application of mindfulness to the body are called the body in some places.
If so, then the mind that arises regretting something not yet done should not be remorse,
but this is not so, because what is not yet done is also called done.
For example, in regretting, one says:
I did not do such a thing before, this is my remorse.
However, this remorse is both good and bad, and does not extend to the indeterminate, because it follows sorrow and because one who is free from craving for desire does not accomplish it.
Indeterminate dharmas do not have such things, but there is regret.
What do I need to do? I ate without digesting.
What do I need this for? I won't paint this wall.
This is the kind of situation.
That mind, as long as it has not yet touched the faculty of sorrow, is only reflection, not yet having arisen as remorse.

If it touches the faculty of sorrow, it then gives rise to remorse. At that time, remorse is the same as the faculty of sorrow. Therefore, it is said that remorse has this kind of characteristic, namely, causing the mind to be depressed.
If the class of mind with remorse is apart from the faculty of sorrow, what causes the mind to be depressed?
Remorse is of four kinds, namely wholesome, unwholesome, each arising based on one basis.

In the class of unwholesome minds that are not shared, it should be known that twenty mental factors arise together, namely the ten universal mental factors, six fundamental afflictions, two fundamental unwholesome mental factors, and two undetermined ones, namely applied thought and sustained thought.
What are called the classes of mind that are not shared?

It is said that this class of mind only has ignorance, without any remaining latent afflictions such as greed. It is the same for those that arise together with wrong views, attachment to views, and attachment to precepts and practices in the class that is not shared.
In the category of universal mental activities, discernment is distinguished and called view, and therefore the number of mental activities is not increased.

The word â€œonlyâ€ in the verse means â€œdistinguishing.â€ It means that only twenty mental activities are definitely associated with view, because regret, etc., may be found in the category of mental activities not common to all. That is, when regret is bad, it is only associated with ignorance and not with other passions, because craving and pride evolve from joy,
and anger evolves from external objects and is gross in form, and therefore it is not associated with regret.
Doubt is indecisive, and regret is decisive, and therefore they do not occur together.
The view of a real self, etc., evolve from joy and are extremely intense, and regret is not like this.
However, this regret occurs in the realm of good and bad actions.
The views are not like this, and therefore they are not associated.
Even though wrong views are associated with sorrow, they are not associated with regret because of two causes.
Therefore when regret is bad, it is only associated with ignorance and may be found in the category of mental activities not common to all.
The same is true of anger, etc.

In a thought that is unwholesome and associated with the passions of craving, hatred, pride, or doubt, there are twenty-one mental activities, twenty as above, plus one of the three passions of craving, etc.

In a thought that is unwholesome and associated with any of the secondary passions such as anger, there are also twenty-one mental activities, twenty as above, plus one of the secondary passions such as anger.
In a thought that is unwholesome and associated with remorse, there are also twenty-one mental activities, i.e., the twenty-one consisting of the above twenty plus remorse.
In a thought that is morally indeterminate and associated with passions that conceal, there are only eighteen mental activities, i.e., the above twenty minus the three passions of anger, etc.

A morally indeterminate thought that is associated with passions that conceal in the realm of desire is associated with the views of personal identity and of extreme views. The meaning of the increase of views should be explained as above.
In a thought that is morally indeterminate and not associated with passions that conceal, there are twelve mental activities, i.e., the ten universal activities, plus memory and samÄdhi.

There is an opinion that regret is also indeterminate. Sorrow, like joy, is not necessarily only a specific mental dharma. In this associated category, there are then thirteen mental activities that occur together.
Because sleepiness is not in opposition to any of the other mental activities, it can occur in all the categories of mind.
In the categories of good, bad, and indeterminate minds, it is added to whichever category it occurs in. The number should be increased as appropriate.

In the indeterminate minds of the stage of craftsmanship, etc., there is a kind of courage, but it is not in accordance with principle, and the practice is not carried out, and therefore there is no zeal.
Also, it is not defiled, and therefore there is no indolence.
There is no faith or faithlessness. This should be understood in the same way.
We have explained the definite number of mental activities occurring with the various minds in the realm of desire. We shall now discuss the upper realms.
A verse says:
In the first trance state, eliminate the bad mind and agitation and sleepiness.
In the middle trance state, also eliminate applied thought. In the upper ones, eliminate sustained thought, etc.
A verse says:
In the first trance state, all the mental activities mentioned above are present, except for the unwholesome states of remorse and sloth, and the rest are all present.
The only unwholesome states are the passions of hatred and the secondary passions of lack of conscience and shame. The rest, such as anger, etc., are absent.
The rest are all present as in the realm of desire.
In the intermediate trance state, the above are absent, and in addition, initial thought is absent, and the rest are all present.
In the second trance state and above, up to the formless realm, the above are absent, and in addition, investigation, etc., are absent.

The word â€œetc.â€ indicates that flattery and deceit are absent. The rest are all present as before, because from the realm of desire up to the heaven of the Brahmapurohita gods, there are distinctions of ruler and minister, lord and subject, etc., and therefore there is flattery and deceit, but these are absent above that.
What are the specific characteristics of shamelessness, lack of conscience, love, and respect?
Verse:
Shamelessness and lack of conscience are not reverential, not seeing fear in offenses,
Love and respect are faith and shame, only existing in the desire and form realms.
Commentary:

The difference between shamelessness and lack of conscience is that regarding virtues and virtuous people, lacking respect, lacking reverence, lacking fear, lacking submission, is called shamelessness.

Virtues refer to precepts and so forth, virtuous people refer to preceptors and so forth. Lacking respect and reverence towards these two objects is the characteristic of shamelessness, which is the Dharma that obstructs reverence and respect.
Or, regarding virtues it is called lacking respect, regarding virtuous people it is called lacking reverence. Lacking fear and lacking submission comprehensively illustrates the previous two.
Or, in sequence, not seeing fear in offenses committed is called lack of conscience.
The dharmas that are censured and detested by contemplatives are called sins.

Not seeing the fearful things among the censured and detested sins, such as the unpleasant and difficult to endure retribution of this world and the next, and the punishment of being reviled, is the characteristic of shamelessness, which means not avoiding the fruits of sins.
What meaning does the phrase not seeing fear want to show?
Is it not seeing that fear, or is it seeing but not being afraid?
The former should show ignorance, and the latter should show wrong views.

This phrase does not show that seeing and not seeing are the substance of shamelessness, but only shows that there is a dharma that is an accompanying defilement, which can serve as the proximate cause for the present non-knowledge and wrong knowledge, and is called shamelessness.
The brief meaning is this: Causing the mind to have no respect for virtues and the virtuous is called shamelessness;
Not avoiding the performance of sins is called having no sense of shame.
Other masters say:
It is called shamelessness because one is not disgusted with or condemns the passions.
It is called lack of conscience because one is not disgusted with or condemns evil conduct.
Some say that
the lack of shame in committing offenses alone is called shamelessness,
while the lack of shame in committing offenses in the presence of others is called lack of conscience.
Some say that
when a good mind is present, one does not consider the cause of retribution and is called shameless;
when one does not consider the fruit of retribution, it is called lack of conscience.
When a good mind is present, one does not consider cause and effect, and therefore the two dharmas arise together in one mind.
This is the opposite explanation of the difference between shame and conscience.
If one has a pure intention and is loved by good people for superior actions, is that called having shame? If one obtains the superior fruit loved by good people, is that called having conscience?
Those who love superior actions and superior fruits must also fear evil causes and suffering fruits.
When any good mind is present, one is certainly not confused about either cause or effect, and therefore shame and conscience can occur together in the same mind.
Therefore other masters, at the beginning of their discussion, say,
Shamelessness is the lack of self-respect with regard to evil deeds that one has done oneself.
Lack of conscience is the lack of respect for others with regard to evil deeds that one has done oneself.
The cause of retribution is present at the time of the action and is therefore called self.
The result of retribution exists only in the future and is therefore called other.
The meaning of this explanation is that the person who commits evil has an impure will and is indifferent to the present evil action and to the future suffering that it will bring about.
The specific characteristics of shamelessness and lack of conscience have been discussed.
The difference between affection and respect is that affection is a kind of faith that is loving and admiring.
There are two kinds of affection: one is defiled and the other is not. The defiled is craving, and the nondefiled is faith.
Faith is also of two kinds: one is the characteristic of acquiescence, and the other is the characteristic of delight.
If one is able to tolerate and accept the existence of a dharma, or if one generates a desire for it, then one has affection for it. This affection is the second kind of faith.

Or, the name of the result is sometimes established on the basis of the cause, and the previous faith is called affection because it is the cause of affection, and there is no error in so designating it.
Respect is the essence of self-respect. As was said in the discussion of the great ground mental activities, â€œThe essence of self-respect is a purity of mind.â€ This is the essence of respect.

However, there are other masters who say,ğŸ”½â€œThat which is revered is called respect. Because of this, one generates self-respect and shame. Therefore, respect is not self-respect.â€ğŸ”½These masters must admit that those who are without self-respect and shame can generate respect, because they hold that respect is generated first and only then is there self-respect and shame.

Those who are without self-respect and shame can generate respect. If you say that at the time of respect there is already self-respect and shame, then you should not say that self-respect and shame are generated only after respect.
If you say that when one is reverential one is not without shame and remorse, but that reverence is not shame, this is also unreasonable, because there is no proof that reverence is not shame.
Shame and remorse do not arise first and then reverence, and one who is shameless should not be able to generate reverence. Also, one who is reverential should not be without shame.
However, if you insist that the substance of reverence is not shame, then you have only empty words and are completely without true meaning.

Therefore, the substance of reverence is a specific form of shame. That is, there is a kind of shame called respect, and this specific form of shame is called reverence, because it takes a pudgala as its object.
Shame is a specific form of respect, because respect is the mastery of the mind, and the nature of mastery of the mind has already been explained as shame.

That is, in the mind there is the power of mastery, which is able to control and subdue, and there is something to be respected. Therefore, it is said that the substance of reverence is a specific form of shame.
Because one has respect for and reveres the honored ones, it is called reverence.
This is the seventh realm or the seventh cause, because it produces a mind that follows and submits to what is respected, and is therefore called shame.
This shame is what is highly regarded, and therefore the substance of this respect is a distinction of shame.
The good meaning is accomplished, and this is proven by this.

When the person is the object, faith and shame are called love and respect. They are not said to arise with the Dharma as the object. Therefore, although love and respect are included in the great wholesome ground dharmas, they are not established as existing in the formless realm.
Other masters say:
Faithfully intimate without attachment is called love;
Looking up to what is respected and following it is called respect.
Other masters say:
The cause of intimacy with good people is called love; not going beyond their words is called respect.
There are also those who say:
Because in the harmonious assembly one sees and is the same as all, it is called love; because one deeply reveres what is to be respected, it is called respect.
These two, love and respect, exist in the desire realm and form realm, but not in the formless realm, because there is no basis for them there.
Thus the distinct characteristics of love and respect have been explained.
What are the distinct characteristics of applied thought and sustained thought, and pride?
Verse:
Applied thought and sustained thought are the coarseness and subtlety of the mind. Pride is the elevation of the mind in relation to others.
Arrogance is the intoxication of the mind due to attachment to one's own qualities, with no regard for others.
Treatise:

The difference between applied thought and sustained thought is that they are the coarseness and subtlety of the mind. The coarse nature of the mind is called applied thought, and the subtle nature of the mind is called sustained thought.
If that is so, then the substance of applied thought and sustained thought is no different from the mind, because the sÅ«tra speaks of two natures in relation to the mind.
This statement is unreasonable, because it does not understand the meaning of the sÅ«tra.

The sÅ«tra says:ğŸ”½That which is the coarse and subtle nature of the mind is called applied thought and sustained thought. Because of the existence of this dharma, the mind arises as coarse, and this dharma is called applied thought;
because of the existence of this dharma, the mind arises as subtle, and this dharma is called sustained thought.

Or, we offer a different interpretation: the substance of the two is different from mind, because we do not say that the coarse nature of mind is called the coarse nature of mind, and the subtle nature of mind is called the subtle nature of mind. How is it that the coarse nature of mind is called the coarse nature of mind based on the coarse nature of mind, and the subtle nature of mind is called the subtle nature of mind based on the subtle nature of mind?
Although two substances can be found in one mind, their increased functions are different, so there is no contradiction.

It is like water and vinegar mixed in equal parts. Although their substances are equal, their functions increase.ğŸ”½In the class of coarse minds, the function of investigation increases, so the function of reflection is damaged and exists but is difficult to perceive;
in the class of subtle minds, the function of reflection increases, so the function of investigation is damaged and exists but is difficult to perceive.

If you say that the function of vinegar increases at all times, so it is not a simile, this statement is unreasonable. I do not definitely say that vinegar is used as a simile for investigation and water for reflection, but I only say that that which has increased function is like vinegar.

Therefore, even though applied thought and sustained thought are present in a single moment of thought, they are distinguished in terms of their functions. Therefore, one moment of thought is neither gross nor subtle.
Even though the natures of craving and delusion are both present in active form, it is said that the mind is associated with craving.
When a certain dharma is dominant in a class of mind, that dharma is said to be the gate through which the class is distinguished.
The general name of the class of mind is distinguished in terms of the dominant function of the formless dharmas.

The specific characteristics of applied thought and sustained thought have been discussed.ğŸ”½Arrogance is the nature of the mind exalting itself in relation to others. It is the evaluation of self and others in terms of the superiority or inferiority of their virtues and abilities, whether real or imagined. The mind exalts itself and despises others, and for that reason it is called arrogance.

Conceit is the nature of the mindâ€™s haughtiness and lack of respect, preceded by attachment to oneâ€™s own dharmas. In the dharmas of oneâ€™s own bravery, wealth, social position, morality, wisdom, family, etc., one first generates attachment, and the mind becomes haughty and disrespectful toward the roots of good. For that reason, it is called conceit.
Those who do not care about the roots of goodness are those who, due to arrogance, do not enjoy cultivating good deeds.
This is the difference between pride and arrogance.
Thus, the different categories and definite differences in the arising of the various mental factors have been explained.
However, the various names and characteristics of the mental factors are established according to their meanings in the sutras. Now, their differences in names and meanings shall be discussed.
Verse:
The substance of mind, thought, and consciousness is one, and mind and mental factors have a basis,
Have objects, have aspects, and have five meanings of association.
Treatise:

Although the three substances of mind, thought, and consciousness are one, their meanings differ in terms such as definition. That is to say, because they accumulate and arise, they are called mind; because they think and ponder, they are called thought; because they cognize and discriminate, they are called consciousness.

The meaning of the Paramarthasamudgata Sutra is to deny the one who cognizes, not the act of cognizing. Or, because of various meanings, it is called mind. It is called thought because it serves as the support for others, and it is called consciousness because it serves as the support for itself.
Or, it is called mind because it is the basis for the designation of the realms, sense bases, and aggregates, or because it causes the continuity to grow, or because it is the seed of rebirth.
In this way, the meanings of the various categories are different, and therefore the three terms mind, thought, and consciousness have different meanings but the same substance.

Just as the three terms mind, thought, and consciousness have different meanings but the same substance, the terms mind and mental factors, having a support, having an object, having an aspect, and being associated, are also like this. Although the meanings are different, the substances are the same.

This means that because the mind and mental factors take the six internal sense bases as their support, they are called having a support.ğŸ”½Because they take form and other objects as their objects, they are called having an object.
Because they give rise to aspects of the various categories of the objects, they are called having an aspect.
They are equal and simultaneous in their union with the other nature and in their activity of taking an object, and for that reason they are said to be associated.
What is meant by equal?
Because of the equality of five things, i.e., because mind and its activities are equal in five ways, they are said to be associated. They are equal in support, object, aspect, time, and substance.
By substance is meant that in a single association, just as the substance of mind is single, so too are the substances of the various activities.
The activities are separate from mind and have their own natures.

However, the VaibhÄá¹£ikas say that there is only mind and no separate activities. Mental activities, mind, and thought are not simultaneous, because their modes of activity and objects are not perceived.
Also, a scripture says that consciousness enters the womb.
Also, a scripture says that mind, thought, and consciousness evolve for a long time and are born in various destinies.
Also, it is said that the person is included in the six elements.
Also, it is said that we do not see any dharma that moves rapidly as does mind.
Also, it is said, â€œWe do not see any dharma that, if not cultivated, is not pliable and not serviceable, just like the mind.â€
Also, it is said that the mind travels far and alone.
Also, there are many disputes about mental activities. Some say that mental activities are only three, some say they are only four, some say they are ten, and some say they are fourteen.
Therefore, there is only consciousness that flows according to the stage, and it is said that there are many kinds of distinctions between mind and mental activities.
Like the juice of sugarcane, like actors and dancers, therefore the separate entities of feeling, etc., cannot be obtained.

However, mind and mental activities are the same in terms of time, object, and nature, and their modes of activity are not different. Their different characteristics are difficult to understand. Therefore a scripture says:
Mind and mental activities are mutually associated, whether it be feeling, conceptualization, volition, or consciousness.
Such dharmas are mixed and inseparable, and their characteristics cannot be distinguished.

However, consciousness and conceptualization are different in their characteristics. That is, in regard to an object, the general understanding is called consciousness, while the specific grasping is called conceptualization or thought. This is because mind is strong.
In many places in the scriptures, it is said that they occur singly, as when it is said that the Buddha came, etc., in order to block the simultaneous occurrence of minds.
Because mental activities are difficult to understand, there are many disputes about them. But how can the fact that there are many disputes lead one to deny their existence?
Do not say that they do not exist in the middle, as well as at the beginning and end.

However, all the treatises believe that mental activities are separate from mind, but there are disputes about the number of mental activities, whether they are more or less than the number of dharmas listed. This is because the scriptures do not give a definite number.
If such things as contact are distinctions of mind, how can mind itself be called a mental activity?
On the basis of what definite principle is consciousness called mind?
And on the basis of what reason is it called a mental activity?

If you say that the substance of the various consciousnesses is mind, and such dharmas as feeling are the species of mind, because these dharmas exist in the continuum of mind and are therefore called mental activities, why donâ€™t you say that the various created dharmas are the substance and species of the great elements, because these dharmas exist in the continuum of earth, etc., and are therefore called created?
Since this is not so, how can that be?
Created dharmas are separate from the great elements, as has been extensively analyzed in the Saá¹ƒyuktÃ¢bhidharmahá¹›daya.
If you ask why we know that mental activities definitely exist apart from mind, it is because of teachings and reason.
A scripture says,
The eye and material objects as conditions give rise to visual consciousness. The union of the three is contact, and feeling, conceptualization, and volition arise together.
These dharmas are the species of mind, and because they are supported by mind and are connected with mind, they are called mental activities.

The term â€œarising togetherâ€ does not refer to immediate succession, but only to the simultaneous arising of mental activities. Also, it does not allow that the substance of mind arises together with itself. Therefore we know that it only refers to the simultaneous arising of mental activities.
We have already discussed mind and mental activities among the dharmas of the formless realm. We shall now discuss the dharmas not associated with mind.
A verse says:
The dharmas not associated with mind are acquisition, nonacquisition, homogeneity,
The two mindless samÄdhis, life, characteristics, name and form, etc.
The commentary says:
The term â€œetc.â€ refers to sentences, phrases, and the nature of their combination.
The term â€œtypeâ€ indicates other imagined dharmas, that is, the types mentioned above, which are the natures of acquisition, etc., apart from acquisition, etc.

These dharmas are not associated with mind, and for that reason they are called dharmas not associated with mind. They are not like mental activities that arise in association with mind, sharing the same support and object as mind.
The term â€œmindâ€ is used to indicate that the acquisition, etc., discussed here are of the same type as mind.
The dharmas of mind and mental activities have the same support and objects as mind, and are also of the same species as mind. In order to distinguish them, the text says â€œnot associated.â€

A verse says:

The treatise says:

The acquisition of dharmas of the three time periods each has three kinds. That is, past dharmas have past acquisition, future acquisition, and present acquisition. Future and present dharmas each have three kinds of acquisition.
This is said in terms of the possibility of their existence. The distinctions within them will be discussed later.
Also, the acquisition of good, etc., dharmas is only good, etc. That is, good, bad, and indeterminate dharmas have three kinds of acquisition, respectively.
